data.title: Athletes Who Died in 1947
data.meta_description: Deaths in sport in 1947. See which famous players, sports stars, managers and coaches died in 1947 or search by date or keyword.
data.text:
Bill Hewitt, American Pro Football HOF end (4 × First-team All-Pro; Chicago Bears, Philadelphia Eagles; one last players to not wear a helmet), dies in a car crash at 37

Josh Gibson

American Baseball HOF catcher (Negro World Series 1943, 44; 12 × NL All-Star; Triple Crown 1936, 37; batting average .466 1943), dies of a brain tumor at 35

Roy Park, Australian cricketer (prolific Victorian bat & official), dies at 54

Fred Barratt, English cricket fast bowler (5 Tests, 5 wickets; Nottinghamshire CCC), dies at 52

Francis MacKinnon, English cricket batsman (1 Test; Kent CCC) and 35th Chief of MacKinnon clan, dies at 98

Stanley Jackson, English cricketer (20 Tests for England 1893-1905), dies at 76

William Starling Burgess, American yacht designer (America's Cup yachts "Enterprise", "Rainbow", "Ranger") and aviation pioneer, dies at 68

Charles Smith, cricketer (batted for South Africa in 1902-03), dies

Johnny Evers, American Baseball HOF 2nd baseman (World Series 1907, 08 Chicago Orphans/Cubs; WS & NL MVP 1914 Boston Braves) and manager (Chicago Cubs/WS), dies of a cerebral hemorrhage at 65

Mar 28 Rudolph Simonsen, Danish composer (Olympic Arts bronze, 1928 - Symphony No. 2 (Hellas)), and educator (Royal Danish Academy, 1916-47), dies at 57

Joe Hardstaff Sr., English cricket batsman (5 Tests; 3 x 50; Nottinghamshire CCC) and umpire (21 Tests), dies at 64

Benny Leonard, American boxer (world lightweight title 1917-25), dies from a heart attack at 51

Charles Bidwill, American Pro Football HOF team owner (Chicago Cardinals 1933-46), dies of pneumonia at 51

Ty LaForest, Canadian baseball player, dies at 30

Hal Chase, American MLB baseball player and manager, dies at 64

Ed Konetchy, American MLB player, dies at 61

Norman Reid, cricketer (Test S Af v Aust 1921-22, 11 & 6, 2-63), dies

Warwick Armstrong, cricketer (50 Tests 1901-21, 2863 runs), dies at 68

George Challenor, West Indian cricketer (played in 1st WI Test side 1928), dies at 59

Vic Willis, American Baseball HOF pitcher (no-hitter 1899; World Series 1909; MLB ERA leader 1899 & strikeout leader 1902; Boston Beaneaters, Pittsburgh Pirates), dies at 71

Nelson Betancourt, Trinidad and Tobago cricket wicket-keeper (WI Test 1930), dies at 42

Man o' War, American thoroughbred racehorse (Preakness Stakes, Belmont Stakes 1920), dies from a heart attack at 30
